title: Research Design
text:
While trust in scientists is moderately high globally (Cologna et al. 2025), climate scientists have consistently been found to be less trusted than scientists from other fields and scientists in general (Druckman et al. 2024; Ghasemi et al. 2025; Schr√∏der 2023; Schug, Bilandzic, and Kinnebrock 2024). Lower trust in climate scientists could hamper societies‚Äô ability to address climate change, resulting in high personal and societal costs.
Strengthening trust in climate scientists matters: Across 55 countries, trust in climate scientists was the strongest predictor of belief in climate change and support for climate policy (Todorova et al. 2025).
Increasing trust in climate scientists may therefore be an important lever to accelerate climate action and strengthen societal resilience to climate change. There is currently only a small number of behavioral intervention studies on increasing trust in climate scientists. The Strengthening Trust in Climate Scientists Megastudy aims to fill this gap.

text:
Megastudy testing 20 interventions to strengthen trust in climate scientists in the US



Jan Pf√§nder1, Madalina Vlasceanu2, Sara M. Constantino2, and Viktoria Cologna1
1Department of Environmental Social Sciences, Swiss Federal Institute of Aquatic Science and Technology (Eawag)
2Department of Environmental Social Sciences, Stanford Doerr School of Sustainability







Author Note
Jan Pf√§nder  https://orcid.org/0009-0009-4389-2807
Madalina Vlasceanu  https://orcid.org/0000-0003-2138-1968
Sara M. Constantino  https://orcid.org/0000-0001-5533-5885
Viktoria Cologna  https://orcid.org/0000-0003-3706-8669
The authors have no conflict of interest to declare.
Correspondence concerning this article should be addressed to Jan Pf√§nder, Department of Environmental Social Sciences, Swiss Federal Institute of Aquatic Science and Technology (Eawag), √úberlandstrasse 133, Switzerland CH-8600 D√ºbendorf, Email: jan.pfaender@eawag.ch



Abstract
Keywords: survey, comparative analysis, trustworthiness, normative assumptions



Megastudy testing 20 interventions to strengthen trust in climate scientists in the US
Climate change is considered one of the most pressing societal issues (Rogelj et al., 2023), necessitating urgent action at both the policymaking and individual level (IPCC, 2023). To believe in human made climate change‚Äîand the fact that it is a problem‚Äîpeople need to trust climate scientists: we typically cannot observe for ouselves how human actions affect the climate‚Äîwe have have to rely on the measures, models, and interpretations of climate scientists. A large-scale study across 55 countries found that trust in climate scientists was the strongest predictor of belief in climate change and support for climate policies (Todorova et al., 2025). Strengthening trust in climate scientists may therefore be an important lever to accelerate climate action.
There is encouraging evidence on how to strengthen trust in scientists in general, but very few studies have targeted climate scientists in particular. For scientists in general, studies have found that using open-science practices (Rosman et al., 2022; J. Schneider et al., 2022; Song et al., 2022) and highlighting successful replications (Hendriks et al., 2020) can increase trust. One study found that presenting participants with an infographic about the scientific process slightly increased trust in scientists (Agley et al., 2021). Exercising intellectual humility‚Äîacknowledging the limits of one‚Äôs knowledge‚Äî has been shown to increase trust in a fictive virologist and a fictive climate scientists (Koetke et al., 2024). In another study, participants tended to acribe more expertise‚Äîa dimensions of trustworthiness‚Äîto scientists, when they present two-sided rather than one-sided arguments (Hendriks et al., 2023). One study found that reading short biographies of scientists made participants perceive the scientists as more trustworthy, presumably demonstrating benevolence (Hautea et al., 2024). Studies targeting trust climate scientists in particular are rare. One study found that messages emphasizing the need for changes in individual behavior or in public policy to address climate change reduced trust in climate scientists (Palm et al., 2020). Another study showed that participants perceived climate scientists as more skilled‚Äîa dimension of trustworthiness‚Äîafter reading a text about the longstanding history and foundations of climate science (Orchinik et al., 2024).
The lack of direct evidence on how to strengthen trust in climate scientists is an issue: While trust in scientists is moderately high globally (Cologna et al., 2025), climate scientists have consistently been found to be less trusted than scientists in general (Ghasemi et al., 2025) and scientists from other disciplines (Druckman et al., 2024; Gligoriƒá et al., 2024; Pf√§nder & Mercier, 2025; Schr√∏der, 2023; Schug et al., 2024). It is therefore not clear how findings regarding scientists more generally transfer to climate scientists specifically.
Another issue is the comparability of current findings: It is difficult to compare the effectiveness of different communication strategies on trust in scientists, because of differences in sample selection, outcome measures, and experimental design. This is all the more important, as not all studies have produced positive results. For example, a registered report testing messages tailored to conservatives in the US did not change trust (Gligoriƒá et al., 2025). Another example is uncertainty communication: One study found no significant effect of uncertainty communication in science museums (Altenm√ºller et al., 2024), and some studies even suggest that communicating uncertainty might reduce trust in scientists (C. R. Schneider et al., 2022; van der Bles et al., 2020).
Here, we aim to address these issues by systematically identifying, testing, and comparing different communication strategies to strengthen trust in climate scientists. To do so, we run a megastudy‚Äî‚Äúa massive field experiment in which many different treatments are tested synchronously in one large sample using a common, objectively measured outcome‚Äù (Milkman et al., 2021). Our megastudy comprises 20 text-based interventions issued from a crowdsourcing process. While trust in climate scientists is the main outcome, we will also assess the interventions‚Äô impact on various other outcome variables, including, for instance, belief in climate change, support for climate policies and public research funding, and taking individual action to foster climate research (by making a donation a research institution). The results of our study therefore have the potential to inform the communication strategies of a wide range of actors‚Äîe.g., universities, research institutes, governments, or NGOs‚Äîlooking to rally support in the fight against climate change.
Methods
The interventions are the result from a crowdsourcing process: In an open call, we have invited researchers and practitioners to collaborate and submit proposals. we received 107 proposals. These proposals have been reviewed by our advisory board, consisting of experts on trust in science and behavioral interventions. We are currently in the process of making the final selection based on the reviewer scores.

title: Variables
text:
Behavioral measures

Donation
To assess consequential and impactful behavior, participants will be given the option to donate a monetary bonus to the American Geophysical Union (AGU), or keep it for themselves. The AGU was chosen because it is the leading scientific association for scientists working on climate change. Participants read following:

‚ÄúFor the next question, we would like you to have the opportunity to donate money to a non-profit or to keep it for yourself. Please decide how you would like to allocate $10 between yourself and the American Geophysical Union (AGU). The AGU is a non-profit, non-partisan scientific association. It is the largest scientific association in the area of climate change in the US, with over 15,000 scientist members. You can give all of the money to the AGU and keep none for yourself, or you can keep all the money for yourself and give none to AGU, or you can pick any split in between. Note: We will randomly select a subset of 100 participants and realize their choices.‚Äù

section: Reliance on scientists for lifestyle choices
text:
Reliance on scientists for lifestyle choices
Scale: from 0 to 100 (sliders)
Adapted from the ‚ÄúWillingness to be vulnerable to scientists‚Äù scale in Cologna et al. (2025), but heavily modified. We retain only one item, as the other two (‚ÄúHow much or little should governments rely on climate scientists‚Äô guidance when making decisions related to climate science?‚Äù and ‚ÄúHow much or little control do you want climate scientists to have on government decisions related to science?‚Äù) were conceptually closer to scientists‚Äô role in policy making. We also make changes to the one item we retain (original: ‚ÄúHow willing are you to rely on climate scientists‚Äô advice when making lifestyle choices (e.g., sustainable transportation, energy use and nutrition)? (1) Not at all, (2) A little, (3) A moderate amount, (4) A lot, (5) A great deal‚Äù), as the endpoints of the original likert scale might be asymmetric. Our modification also aligns better with our scale for measuring scientists‚Äô role in policy making.

title: A Megastudy on Strengthening Trust in Climate Scientists
text:
Recently, a large-scale study across 55 countries found that trust in climate scientists is the strongest predictor of belief in climate change and support for climate policies. Strengthening trust in climate scientists may therefore be an important lever for accelerating climate action. However, there is currently little evidence on how to strengthen trust in climate scientists.
We aim to address this gap by systematically identifying, testing, and comparing communication strategies designed to strengthen trust in climate scientists. To this end, we are conducting a megastudy‚Äîa large-scale field experiment in which many different interventions are tested simultaneously within a single, large sample using a common, objectively measured outcome.
The study will be conducted in the United States, where climate research is particularly threatened by funding cuts and public beliefs about climate change are highly polarized. Through an open call, we invited researchers and practitioners to collaborate and received 107 intervention proposals. From these, we selected 20 interventions, ranging from reading about climate science to discussing the topic with LLMs.
We will complete the preregistration in January and collect data from approximately 21,000 U.S. participants in February. By the time of the conference in Hohenheim at the end of June, a preprint will be available.
